title: AITA for telling my husband I don’t want to participate in his fantasy football league?
self_text: I (30F) have always found fantasy football confusing and frankly boring. My husband (32M) is *obsessed*. He spends hours researching stats, trading players, and generally stressing over his team. This year, he decided to start a league with his friends and insisted I join. He said it would be “fun” and a way for me to bond with his friends’ wives. He even drafted a team for me! I reluctantly agreed, hoping to appease him, but I haven’t checked the standings once. He keeps texting me updates and asking for my input on trades, and I’ve just been responding with vague answers like “Sounds good!” or “Whatever you think.” Yesterday, he was visibly frustrated that I hadn’t logged in to make lineup changes. He launched into a lecture about how seriously he takes the league and how unfair it is that I’m not participating. I snapped and told him I’m just not interested, I don’t understand it, and I don’t want to pretend to care. He accused me of ruining his fun and making him look bad in front of his friends. He’s now giving me the silent treatment. I feel bad for hurting his feelings, but I also feel like I shouldn’t have to participate in something I don’t enjoy just to make him happy. AITA?

title: AITA for not wanting to go to my family’s Christmas Eve party?
self_text: I (26F) have a complicated relationship with my family, particularly my mother (60F). She’s very controlling and critical, and tends to make gatherings more stressful than enjoyable. This year, she's insisted on hosting Christmas Eve at her house, despite knowing I’m trying to establish boundaries. I told her I’d prefer to spend a quiet Christmas Eve with my boyfriend (27M) and our cat, but she’s reacted poorly. She’s accusing me of abandoning tradition, prioritizing my boyfriend over family, and generally making me feel guilty. She's been texting me relentlessly about how disappointed she is and how it’s “selfish” of me to not participate. My siblings (both in their 30s) are siding with my mom, saying I need to “grow up” and “make an effort.” I’ve calmly explained my reasons – needing a peaceful holiday and protecting my mental health – but they dismiss it as me being overly sensitive. I’m starting to feel really worn down and pressured. My boyfriend supports my decision wholeheartedly and thinks I should stand my ground. AITA for wanting to skip the family drama and have a calm Christmas Eve?

title: AITA for refusing to let my boyfriend’s mom decorate my house for Christmas?
self_text: My (28F) boyfriend (30M) and I have been together for 5 years. This will be our first Christmas in our *own* house – we just bought it in October. His mom (60sF) is… a lot. She’s very opinionated and loves to take charge. She’s already been hinting for weeks about decorating our house for Christmas, offering to bring over boxes of ornaments and suggesting themes. I appreciate her enthusiasm, but I have a very specific aesthetic I’m going for – minimalist Scandinavian, lots of neutrals, cozy textures, etc. Her style is… maximalist grandma chic. Think bright colors, lots of figurines, tinsel everywhere. Basically, the polar opposite of what I envision. I’ve subtly tried to steer the conversation towards us handling the decorating ourselves, emphasizing that we want to establish our own traditions, but she keeps pushing. Yesterday, she outright asked if she could come over next weekend and “transform” the house. I politely but firmly said no. I explained that we appreciate her offer, but we’d like to decorate ourselves and create our own Christmas ambiance. She was visibly hurt and accused me of being ungrateful and excluding her. My boyfriend is stuck in the middle, trying to appease both of us. He says I was too harsh and should have just let her decorate a *small* corner of the house. I maintain that it’s our house, our taste, and we should have complete control over how it looks. She’s now giving him the silent treatment, and he’s sulking. AITA for protecting my decorating vision and setting boundaries with his mom?

title: AITA for telling my husband I’m done pretending to like his hobbies?
self_text: I (32F) have been married to “Mark” (35M) for seven years. Mark loves tabletop RPGs – Dungeons & Dragons, Pathfinder, you name it. He’s *really* into it. He’s been trying to get me to participate for years. I’ve always politely declined, saying it’s just not my thing. But he kept pushing, so I started attending sessions with him, hoping to appease him. I pretended to be invested, asked questions, tried to follow along… it was exhausting. I’m not a gamer, I don’t enjoy fantasy settings, and frankly, I find the whole thing incredibly boring. Over the years, I've spent hundreds of hours sitting at his table, rolling dice and pretending to care about goblin encounters. He's always beaming and thanking me for "trying," but it feels incredibly performative on my end. Last night, after a particularly long session, I snapped. He was excitedly recounting a battle strategy, and I just blurted out, “Honestly, I hate this. I’ve been pretending for years, and I’m done.” He was visibly hurt. He said he thought I was having fun, and that it meant a lot to him that I supported his interests. I admitted I was supporting *him*, not the hobby. He accused me of being dismissive and uncaring. Now he’s giving me the silent treatment. I feel bad for hurting his feelings, but I also feel relieved to finally be honest. AITA for telling him I’m done pretending to like his hobbies?

title: AITA for refusing to participate in a Secret Santa with a $100 limit?
self_text: I (28F) work in a fairly small office of about 15 people. We've done a Secret Santa for the past few years, and the limit has always been $20-$30. This year, someone suggested raising the limit to $100. I thought this was ridiculous, especially considering how tight money is for a lot of us right now. I voiced my opinion, saying that $100 was excessive and unnecessary, and I'd rather we stick to the previous limit. Several people agreed with me, but the organizer insisted that a higher limit allows for more thoughtful gifts. I reluctantly agreed to participate, but stated I wouldn't be spending $100. The organizer then announced that if you weren't willing to spend $100, you weren't allowed to participate at all. I feel this is unfair and exclusionary. I'm perfectly happy to contribute a reasonable amount, but I refuse to be pressured into spending beyond my comfort level. I’ve now been labeled as a Scrooge by a few coworkers. AITA for refusing to comply?

title: AITA for not wanting to participate in my coworker’s secret santa?
self_text: I (28F) work in a fairly small office of about 15 people. Every year we do a Secret Santa, with a $25 limit. Usually, I enjoy it, and try to get thoughtful gifts. This year, however, I’m really strapped for cash. Between rising bills and unexpected vet expenses, I’m barely making ends meet. I confided in a coworker, Sarah (30F), about my financial struggles, and she was sympathetic. She suggested I opt out of Secret Santa this year, which I agreed to. I told our organizer, Mark (40M), that I wouldn’t be participating, and he was understanding. However, Sarah apparently went around telling everyone I opted out *because* I think Secret Santa is stupid and wasteful. Now, people are giving me dirty looks, and Mark just cornered me and said it was “really rude” of me to refuse to participate in team bonding. He implied I’m being antisocial and that my refusal is hurting morale. I tried to explain that it’s a financial issue, not a philosophical one, but he wouldn’t listen. He insisted I still owe it to the team to pitch in. I’m really frustrated. I feel like my private conversation with Sarah was betrayed, and I’m being pressured to spend money I don’t have. AITA for not wanting to participate, and for keeping my reasons private?

title: AITA for not wanting to participate in my coworker's fantasy football draft?
self_text: I (32M) work in a fairly casual office environment. A coworker, Mark (28M), is *obsessed* with fantasy football. Every year he tries to get everyone in the office to participate, and every year most people politely decline. He’s generally respectful when people say no, but pushes pretty hard. This year he’s really ramping up the pressure. He’s created a Slack channel dedicated solely to the league, sends constant updates, and corners people at the coffee machine to try and convince them. title: AITA for refusing to let my husband’s coworker borrow my car?
self_text: My (30F) husband (32M) works as a mechanic. A coworker of his, Kevin (28M), recently totaled his car. He accused me of being selfish and prioritizing a car over helping someone. I maintain that it's my car, and I have a right to feel secure about who drives it. AITA for refusing to lend my car to my husband’s coworker?

title: AITA for refusing to participate in a secret santa with a $100 limit?
self_text: I (26F) work in a fairly small office of about 15 people. We’ve done Secret Santa for the past few years, and the limit has always been $20-$30. title: AITA for refusing to let my boyfriend’s mom borrow my car?
self_text: My (25F) boyfriend (27M) and I have been dating for 3 years. His mom, Carol (60sF), has always been a bit…overbearing. She frequently asks for favors, and my boyfriend usually caves to appease her. Lately, she's been needing rides everywhere since her license was suspended due to too many speeding tickets. My boyfriend works long hours, so she asked *me* if she could borrow my car a few times a week to go grocery shopping, attend bingo nights, and visit friends. I politely declined, explaining that I rely heavily on my car for work and errands, and I’m not comfortable lending it out regularly. She acted insulted and accused me of being selfish and not wanting to help her family. My boyfriend tried to mediate, but she doubled down, saying I was deliberately trying to make her life difficult. She then started guilting me by saying she’s elderly and needs assistance. I understand she's in a tough spot, but I’m not responsible for providing her transportation. I suggested she explore public transport or ask other family members for help, but she dismissed those options. My boyfriend is now upset with me, saying I’m causing unnecessary tension with his mom and should just let her borrow the car. He argues it’s a small gesture that would make a big difference to her. I feel like I'm being pressured to sacrifice my convenience and comfort for someone who isn't even treating me with respect. AITA for setting boundaries and refusing to lend my car?

title: AITA for refusing to help my coworker with her fantasy football team?
self_text: I (32M) work in an office with a fairly competitive Fantasy Football league. About half the office participates. I’ve consistently finished near the bottom every year – I’m just not very good at it. My coworker, Sarah (28F), is a *very* skilled player and consistently wins or places highly. She’s also…intense about it. This year, Sarah’s team is struggling. Badly. Last week, she cornered me at the coffee machine and started grilling me about my bench players, asking detailed questions about their stats and potential. I answered politely, but she kept pressing, practically begging me to suggest trades she could make to improve her team. I told her I was happy to chat about general football, but I wasn't comfortable advising her strategy, especially since we're competing against each other. She got visibly frustrated, accusing me of being unhelpful and ruining her chances of winning. She’s been giving me the silent treatment ever since, and several other coworkers have commented that she’s upset with me. I feel like I’m perfectly within my rights to not help someone beat me in a competition, but now I’m wondering if I’m being an AH. AITA?

title: AITA for not wanting to participate in my coworker’s secret santa?
self_text: I (28F) work in a small office with about 10 people. Every year we do a Secret Santa, with a $25 limit. Usually, I participate and enjoy it. I told Sarah (35F), who organizes it, that I unfortunately couldn’t participate this year due to financial constraints. She was… not happy. She insisted it’s “just $25” and that it’s “about the spirit of the season.” I explained again that it wasn’t feasible for me right now, but she kept pressing, suggesting I could re-gift something or DIY a gift. I finally said I wasn’t going to be pressured into spending money I didn’t have. title: AITA for not wanting to participate in Secret Santa with my coworkers?
self_text: I (28F) work in a fairly small office (about 15 people). Every year we do a Secret Santa with a $25 limit. I generally don’t participate because I find it stressful trying to find something for someone I barely know, and honestly, I’m not thrilled about receiving a random gift either. This year, our boss strongly encouraged participation and made a big announcement about it, emphasizing how it builds team morale. I reluctantly put my name in, hoping to fly under the radar as usual. However, my coworker Sarah (30sF) found out I don’t *actually* buy gifts and confronted me. She told HR, and now HR is involved, suggesting I should either participate fully or withdraw my name. I’m frustrated because it feels like a silly tradition that’s being overly enforced. I don’t want to cause conflict, but I also don’t want to be forced to spend money on something I don’t enjoy. AITA?

title: AITA for telling my coworker her baby is ugly?
self_text: I (28F) work in an office with a lot of people I've known for years. Sarah (32F) just had a baby and brought in pictures to show everyone. Honestly, the baby is… not cute. It has a really squished face and looks kind of grumpy all the time. I tried to be polite and say something generic like “Oh, babies change so much!” but Sarah pressed me and asked what *I* thought. title: AITA for not wanting to help my brother build his PC?
self_text: My (26M) brother (24M) recently decided he wants to get into PC gaming. He’s always been tech illiterate, relying on me for everything related to computers. He asked me to build his PC for him, saying he trusts my expertise and it would take him forever to research everything. I agreed, figuring it would be a fun project and a good bonding experience. I spent HOURS researching components, making sure everything was compatible and optimized for his budget (~$1500). I even found some deals and saved him money. I presented him with the parts list and he approved it. Now, he wants *me* to physically assemble the PC too. I told him I wasn't comfortable with that. Building a PC isn't rocket science, and there are tons of YouTube tutorials. I offered to guide him through the process step-by-step, answering questions as he builds it himself. He's furious. He claims I’m being a jerk and that since I did all the research, I should just finish the job. He says he'll screw it up if he tries himself and waste all the money we spent on the parts. He’s now accusing me of wanting to lord my technical knowledge over him. I feel like he's trying to exploit my skills and doesn't want to learn anything himself. AITA for refusing to build the PC for him and instead offering guidance?

title: AITA for telling my husband I’m done pretending to like his hobbies?
self_text: My (32F) husband (34M) loves Warhammer 40k. He’s been into it since he was a teenager. Initially, I tried to be supportive. I asked him about it, listened to him ramble about lore, even attempted to paint a miniature with him (it was a disaster). But honestly? It bores me to tears. It’s expensive, time-consuming, and frankly, looks like a bunch of plastic figurines to me. Over the years, I’ve pretended to be interested for the sake of keeping the peace. I’ve complimented his painting, feigned excitement over battles, and nodded along to discussions I didn’t understand. I thought I was being a good wife. Lately, though, it’s become exhausting. He’s poured more and more time and money into it, and it feels like our quality time together has dwindled. Last night, he was excitedly describing a new army he was building, and I just snapped. I told him bluntly that I’m done pretending. I said I don’t care about Warhammer, I find it tedious, and I’m tired of acting like I do. He was hurt and angry, accusing me of belittling his passion and being dismissive of something that brings him joy. He said I’ve been lying to him all these years and now he doesn’t know if he can trust me. I admit, it wasn’t delivered delicately. But I felt like I needed to be honest. He’s now giving me the silent treatment. My friends are divided – some say I was right to be honest, others say I should have just continued to pretend. AITA for finally admitting I don’t care about his hobby?

title: AITA for telling my coworker her baby is ugly?

AITA for stating my honest opinion (even if unintentionally)?

title: AITA for not wanting to participate in Secret Santa with my coworkers?
self_text: I (32F) work in a fairly small office (about 15 people). Every year we do a Secret Santa with a $25 limit. I generally don't participate because I'm not really into gifting, and honestly, it causes me anxiety trying to find something someone will *actually* like. This year, my boss strongly encouraged everyone to participate, framing it as a "team building exercise." I reluctantly signed up. I drew the name of Kevin (45M), a coworker who is notoriously difficult. He's constantly complaining, negative, and frankly, kind of rude to everyone. I overheard him making a dismissive comment about my work ethic last week. I've been brainstorming for weeks, but everything feels inadequate or like he'd just complain about it. I finally settled on a nice box of gourmet chocolates – universally appealing, right? I handed it to him today, and he opened it, glanced inside, and said, "Oh. Chocolate. Really? I'm diabetic." He then proceeded to loudly lament about how he "can't even *look* at chocolate" and how it was a "thoughtless gift." Several coworkers witnessed this, and now I'm mortified. My boss subtly gave me a disapproving look. I feel awful, but also like I shouldn’t have been pressured into participating in the first place, especially knowing I'd drawn Kevin. AITA for not anticipating his dietary restrictions and for not wanting to partake in a forced "fun" activity?

title: AITA for refusing to let my husband's coworker use our vacation home?
self_text: My (32F) husband (35M) and I recently purchased a small cabin in the mountains as a vacation home. It’s fairly secluded and was a big splurge for us, something we’ve been saving for years to achieve. His coworker, Mark (30M), knows about the cabin because my husband mentions it occasionally. Mark is going through a messy divorce and confided in my husband that he desperately needs a getaway to clear his head. He then *asked* if he could use our cabin for a week, suggesting he’d contribute to utilities and cleaning costs. My husband immediately said yes, but I was blindsided. I didn't even get consulted. I told my husband absolutely not. This is *our* private retreat, meant for us to disconnect and recharge. Letting a coworker use it – especially one going through a tough time – feels like a massive boundary violation. My husband is furious with me, accusing me of being heartless and not understanding Mark’s situation. He says it’s just a week and we can go another time. I countered that it’s not about the timing, it’s about principle. I don’t want random people having access to our safe space, and I definitely don’t want to be responsible for someone else’s emotional baggage on *our* vacation. He’s now giving me the silent treatment and says I’m ruining his friendship with Mark. AITA for digging my heels in?

title: AITA for not wanting to participate in my husband’s fantasy football draft?

title: AITA for not wanting to help my brother build his PC?
self_text: My (25M) brother (22M) has decided he wants to build his own gaming PC. He’s never built a PC before, and has admitted he knows virtually nothing about components. He asked me to help him, and I initially said yes, figuring it would be a fun bonding experience. However, he immediately started listing off increasingly ridiculous demands. My parents are siding with him, saying I should just “be a good brother” and help him out. AITA for setting boundaries and refusing to build his PC for him?

title: AITA for getting upset over a birthday surprise?
self_text:
My (25F) boyfriend (27M) and I have been together for 3 years. His birthday is next week and I've been subtly hinting at things I'd like – concert tickets, a specific restaurant, etc. He kept deflecting, saying he had a surprise planned. Cool, I thought! I love surprises. 

Yesterday, his mom called me, practically giddy, telling me about the elaborate birthday party she's planning for him. Apparently, it's a huge bash with all his relatives, a bouncy castle, a catered BBQ, and a clown. She even invited *my* parents, which is nice, but also…weird. I expressed my disappointment to my boyfriend, saying I wished we could have celebrated just the two of us, or at least had some input on the party. He got defensive, saying his mom puts a lot of effort into these things and I should be grateful. He accused me of ruining his birthday before it even happened.

AITA for being upset about a surprise party that isn’t really *for* us? I feel like my feelings are being dismissed and I'm just supposed to pretend to be thrilled about something I genuinely dislike.

title: AITA for not wanting to participate in a Secret Santa with a strict theme?
self_text: My work organizes a Secret Santa every year, and participation is strongly encouraged (though not mandatory). This year, my boss announced the theme: “Handmade Gifts ONLY.” I am…not crafty. At all. I can barely sew a button, and my attempts at painting result in abstract messes. title: AITA for not wanting to go to my coworker’s baby shower?

It’s not overwhelming, but it’s definitely present and becoming distracting. I've noticed it for about a week now. I've tried subtly opening a window or spraying air freshener, but it doesn’t seem to help. Other coworkers have also subtly commented on it, but no one has directly addressed Sarah. Today, during a meeting, the smell was particularly strong. I leaned over to another coworker and whispered, “Does anyone else smell that?” They nodded. Frustrated, I turned to Sarah and said, “Hey, I don’t want to embarrass you, but you might want to check your deodorant. There’s a slight odor.” She immediately burst into tears, excused herself, and ran to the restroom. Our boss then pulled me aside and told me I handled the situation poorly and was unprofessional. She said I should have spoken to HR instead. I maintain that I was trying to be discreet and helpful, and she may have an underlying medical condition causing the odor. AITA for addressing the issue directly?

title: AITA for not wanting to participate in my coworker’s Secret Santa?
self_text: I (32F) work in a fairly small office of about 15 people. Every year we do a Secret Santa, and participation is generally encouraged, but never *required*. This year, my coworker Sarah (28F) is spearheading the effort and has been VERY enthusiastic about it – bordering on pushy. She’s repeatedly asked if I’ve signed up, emailed reminders, and even cornered me at the coffee machine to ask. I’ve politely deflected each time, saying I’m “really busy this year” and “trying to save money.” Which is true, I am busy, and money IS tight. I just…don’t want to participate. I don’t really *know* most of these people well enough to want to buy them a gift, and frankly, the whole thing feels like a pointless obligation. Sarah seems genuinely hurt that I won’t participate. She said, “But it’s supposed to be FUN!” and implied I was ruining the spirit of the office. I feel bad for disappointing her, but I also feel like I shouldn’t be pressured into doing something I don’t want to do. AITA for not joining the Secret Santa?

title: AITA for not wanting to attend my coworker’s baby shower?
self_text: I (32F) work in a fairly small office – about 15 people total. A coworker, Sarah (28F), is pregnant and having a baby shower next month. Normally, I participate in office celebrations, chipping in for gifts and attending events. However, I *really* dislike Sarah. She’s consistently condescending, frequently interrupts me in meetings, and generally makes my work life unpleasant. I’ve tried to be polite and professional, but she’s just…difficult. Several other coworkers have confided that they feel similarly about her, but we all maintain civility for the sake of the workplace. I’ve already purchased a gift from the group collection. Now, Sarah is actively soliciting RSVPs and repeatedly asking if I’m coming. She even cornered me in the breakroom today and said, “It would mean a lot to me if you were there.” I politely said I was unsure if I could make it due to a prior commitment (which isn’t a complete lie – I was planning a quiet evening at home). She pressed further, saying, “Oh, come on, it’s just a few hours!” I felt pressured and reluctantly said I’d try to attend. But honestly, I dread the thought of spending an afternoon celebrating with her. Other coworkers have suggested I just suck it up for a few hours, but I feel like I’d be miserable. I'm wondering if it's acceptable to decline again and just send the gift? AITA for not wanting to spend my free time with someone I dislike, even for a supposedly joyous occasion?

title: AITA for not wanting to participate in a Secret Santa with a strict theme?
self_text: My work organizes a Secret Santa every year. Usually it’s fairly open-ended – a price limit and maybe a general guideline like “something fun” or “something cozy.” This year, however, the organizer (Karen, predictably) has decreed that *everyone* must gift something related to Disney villains. I genuinely despise Disney. It feels childish and frankly, I have zero interest in purchasing a Maleficent mug or a Cruella De Vil keychain for anyone. I’ve expressed this to Karen, stating I’d gladly contribute the equivalent monetary value to charity instead, but she insists participation is mandatory and the theme must be adhered to. Several coworkers have privately told me they feel similarly, but are too afraid of Karen’s wrath to speak up. I’m considering just re-gifting something random and hoping for the best, but I suspect that would escalate things dramatically. AITA for refusing to engage in a themed gift exchange I actively dislike?

title: AITA for not wanting to attend my coworker’s baby shower?

title: AITA for refusing to let my husband’s coworker borrow money?
self_text: My (32F) husband (34M) works as a software engineer. A coworker of his, Mark (30M), recently asked my husband for a loan of $5000. Mark claims he needs it for urgent medical bills for his mother. My husband told him he wasn't comfortable lending him that much money, but offered to help Mark find resources for financial assistance programs. Mark then came *directly to me*, bypassing my husband, and asked if I would lend him the money instead, stating he trusts me more and knows my husband is “tight with his money”. I immediately said no. I explained that we have financial goals we're saving for (downpayment on a house) and we don't generally lend large sums of money to acquaintances. Mark got visibly upset, accusing me of being unsympathetic and implying my husband and I are wealthy and wouldn’t miss the money. He then launched into a detailed description of his mother’s illness, attempting to guilt trip me. I calmly repeated that I wasn't able to help financially. My husband is furious with me for not just saying yes to appease Mark and avoid conflict. He argues it would have been a small gesture of kindness and that Mark is a good person going through a tough time. I feel strongly that we shouldn’t be pressured into giving away money, especially when it jeopardizes our own financial future. AITA for standing firm on our boundaries?

title: AITA for not wanting to participate in my coworker’s secret santa?
self_text: I (28F) work in a fairly small office of about 15 people. Every year we do a Secret Santa, and it's generally pretty harmless. This year, however, one of my coworkers, Kevin (35M), announced he's participating *with* his girlfriend. Meaning, they're a team and will be gifting something jointly. Several people have voiced concerns that this isn’t really in the spirit of Secret Santa, but no one has said anything directly to Kevin. I’m honestly just annoyed. It feels unfair – they’ll inevitably get a nicer gift than someone shopping for a single person on a limited budget. More importantly, I'm currently saving for a downpayment on a house and really can’t afford to spend $50-$75 on a gift right now. I’ve participated every year previously, but I’m really strapped for cash. When the signup sheet went around, I reluctantly put my name down, hoping someone would drop out. Nobody did. Now I’m being pressured to come up with a gift idea. I told a coworker I was having trouble budgeting for it this year, and she suggested I just re-gift something. I’m not comfortable with that. I’m considering just opting out altogether, but I’m worried about seeming like a Scrooge and damaging my relationships at work. AITA for not wanting to participate, especially given the Kevin/girlfriend situation?

title: AITA for not wanting to babysit my niece because her mom lets her eat crayons?
self_text: My sister (30F) has a 4 year old daughter, Lily. I (25F) generally like Lily, but my sister is… a lot. She’s very lax with parenting, to put it mildly. Multiple times I’ve witnessed Lily eating things she shouldn’t – dirt, bugs, once a crayon. When I pointed it out, my sister shrugged and said Lily “likes the taste.” She claims Lily’s stomach is “strong” and it builds immunity. I’m really concerned for Lily’s health, but it’s not my place to parent my niece. Anyway, my sister asked me to babysit Lily this weekend so she and her husband can go on a date. I said I couldn’t, citing a previous commitment (which is true, I’m volunteering at an animal shelter). She pushed, saying it’s really important and she can’t find anyone else. I repeated that I already had plans. Then she launched into a rant about how I’m “never available” and “don’t care about family.” I calmly explained that my concern isn’t availability, it’s that I’m uncomfortable supervising Lily unsupervised knowing her tendencies to ingest questionable objects. She hung up on me. Now my mom is calling me, saying I’m being unreasonable and need to apologize to my sister. She says I’m exaggerating and Lily “only eats a *little* crayon.” AITA for prioritizing my discomfort and concerns about Lily’s safety over appeasing my sister and mom?

title: AITA for refusing to participate in my coworker’s secret santa?

title: AITA for refusing to help my coworker with her fantasy football team?
self_text:

\

\

title: AITA for telling my coworker she smells?

title: AITA for ghosting my coworker after he confessed his feelings?
self_text: I (28F) work with Mark (32M). We’ve been coworkers for about a year and always got along – friendly banter, occasional lunch breaks together, generally a positive working relationship. Is completely ghosting him the worst way to handle this?

title: AITA for refusing to let my husband’s coworker borrow my car?
self_text: My (32F) husband (35M) works as a mechanic. A coworker of his, Mark (28M), recently had his car totaled. My husband told me Mark asked *him* if he could borrow our car while he figures things out. My husband, without consulting me, told Mark he’d ask. He came to me and said Mark really needed it for work and to get groceries, and asked if we could lend it to him for a week or two. I said absolutely not. We only have one car, and I rely on it heavily for getting to work, grocery shopping, and taking our dog to vet appointments. I explained that lending our only mode of transportation would significantly disrupt our lives. My husband got upset, accusing me of being unsympathetic and said Mark was a good guy who really needed the help. He also pointed out that he’s always willing to help his coworkers. I countered that it’s easy to be generous when it doesn't negatively impact *your* daily routine. He's now giving me the silent treatment and says I'm being unreasonable. I feel like he completely disregarded my needs and responsibilities by even asking me without discussing it first. AITA for refusing to let his coworker borrow our car?

title: AITA for refusing to let my husband’s coworker borrow money?
self_text: My (32F) husband (35M) works as a mechanic. He’s really good at his job and brings home a steady income. A coworker of his, Mark (40M), is consistently asking to borrow money from my husband. It started small – $20 for lunch, $50 for gas. My husband, being a kind person, obliged a few times. But it’s escalating. Last week Mark asked for $300 to cover a vet bill for his dog. My husband lent it to him, but it took Mark almost a week to pay it back, and my husband had to ask repeatedly. Now Mark is asking for $800 for “emergency car repairs.” He claims he needs to get to work or he’ll lose his job. My husband is hesitant, and rightfully so. I strongly advised him *not* to lend Mark any more money. I told him Mark needs to learn to manage his finances and relying on my husband isn't helping him. I suggested Mark explore options like a loan or assistance programs. My husband feels bad for Mark and thinks we should help him out, but I’m worried we’re being taken advantage of. He said I’m being unsympathetic. Mark overheard us arguing about it at work and apparently is now upset with *me*, saying I’m “ruining things” and making his life harder. My husband is now caught in the middle, feeling pressured by both of us. AITA for digging my heels in and refusing to let my husband continue lending money to his coworker?

title: AITA for refusing to let my boyfriend's mom borrow my car?
self_text: I (25F) have a reliable car that I worked hard to purchase. My boyfriend (27M) and I have been together for 3 years. His mom (60sF) recently had her car break down and is waiting for it to be repaired, which could take weeks. She asked my boyfriend if she could borrow *my* car in the meantime. He asked me, and I immediately said no. I need my car for work, errands, and generally having independence. Public transportation isn’t great where we live. His mom lives nearby and could easily utilize rideshares or ask other family members. My boyfriend is now upset with me, saying I’m being unfair and that it’s just temporary. He claims his mom is really stressed about being stranded and I’m making things harder for her. I told him it's not my responsibility to solve his mom’s transportation problems, and I value having my own reliable transport too much to risk lending it out. He’s now giving me the silent treatment. AITA for prioritizing my own needs and refusing to lend out my car?

title: AITA for telling my coworker she looks like Danny Devito?
self_text: I (28M) work in an office with a fairly relaxed environment. One of my coworkers, Mark (35M), is… stout. Not obese, but definitely shorter and wider than most people. Without thinking, I blurted out, “Wow, Mark, you look like Danny DeVito today!” intending it as a playful jab. He immediately went silent and visibly bristled. But I'm starting to wonder if I was completely out of line. AITA?

title: AITA for getting upset over my husband suggesting I get Botox?
self_text: My (32F) husband (34M) and I were celebrating our anniversary last night. He surprised me with reservations at a nice restaurant and afterwards, he started talking about how much he loves my smile. Which was sweet, but then he said, “You know, if you got a little Botox, it would be *perfect*.” I was floored. I’ve never expressed any desire to get Botox or fillers, and I’m generally pretty confident in my appearance. I have a few fine lines, but I think they’re normal for my age. I told him I didn’t appreciate him implying I needed to change my face and that I liked my smile the way it is. title: AITA for refusing to help my brother financially after he gambled away his stimulus check?
